title: Vestibular Schwannoma Presenting as Sudden Sensorineural Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I lost hearing in my right ear abruptly two days ago. I also have constant ringing, some dizziness, and loud sounds hurt that ear.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset (2 days prior to initial visit).
problem_summary.course: Acute decline followed by significant recovery after steroid treatment.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Constant tinnitus (RE), slight imbalance, hyperacusis (RE), aural fullness (RE).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty hearing on the phone and localizing sound initially; improved after treatment.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Evaluation of sudden hearing loss and potential recovery.

history.present_illness: Patient reported right ear hearing declined abruptly 2 days prior. Denies URI or illness.
history.otologic_history: Denies otalgia or history of ear infections.
history.patient_goals: Diagnosis and management of sudden hearing loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear within normal limits. Right ear normal at 250 Hz sloping to moderately severe to severe SNHL from 750-8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear normal. Right ear showed moderately severe loss for speech reception and very poor word recognition (rollover not specified but score is disproportionately poor).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Left ipsi/contra normal. Right ipsi present but elevated at 1k/2k Hz. Right contra absent at 500-4000 Hz. Reflex decay negative in Left ear; could not test Right due to absent thresholds.

history.present_illness: Patient returned 2 weeks later following otology consult and 12-day prednisone taper. Reports hearing improved significantly and feels normal. Occasional tinnitus persists.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Significant recovery. Bilateral hearing within normal limits, except for a slight SNHL notch at 4000 Hz in the right ear.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal speech reception and excellent word recognition bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes present within normal limits bilaterally. Reflex decay negative bilaterally.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Left ear: Normal absolute and interpeak latencies. Right ear: Normal Wave I, delayed absolute III and V. Prolonged I-III and I-V interpeak latencies. Abnormal interaural Wave V latency difference. Consistent with retrocochlear dysfunction.

tests.name: MRI
tests.key_findings: Medium-sized (2.1-cm) solitary right Vestibular Schwannoma originating in the vestibular portion of the 8th nerve, just within the IAC.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient initially presented with a sudden, moderately severe to severe sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear with disproportionately poor word recognition. Following steroid treatment, pure-tone thresholds and speech recognition recovered to essentially normal levels. However, ABR testing revealed significant retrocochlear signs (prolonged I-V latency) on the right side, and subsequent MRI confirmed a 2.1 cm Vestibular Schwannoma.
counseling_points: Although your hearing has recovered beautifully with the steroid treatment, the ABR test showed a delay in the nerve signal on the right side.
The MRI confirmed that this delay is caused by a benign growth called a Vestibular Schwannoma on your hearing and balance nerve.
Because the tumor is medium-sized and pressing on the nerve, we need to discuss management options, likely leaning toward surgery to remove it while trying to preserve this recovered hearing.
It is important to know that hearing recovery after sudden loss does not rule out a tumor, which is why we performed the full workup.
notes_for_actor: In the first visit, you are anxious about the sudden loss and the loud ringing.
In the second visit, you are relieved and happy that your hearing came back, perhaps skeptical that you still need more testing (ABR/MRI) since you feel 'cured'.
You should express surprise that a tumor was found despite your hearing returning to normal.
